etymologies: Old English træppe (in coltetræppe ‘Christ's thorn’); related to Middle Dutch trappe and medieval Latin trappa, of uncertain origin. The verb dates from late Middle English

definitions: a device or enclosure designed to catch and retain animals, typically by allowing entry but not exit or by catching hold of a part of the body

examples.text: the squirrels ravaged the saplings, despite the baited traps

shortDefinitions: device designed to catch and retain animals

definitions: the compartment from which a greyhound is released at the start of a race.
shortDefinitions: compartment from which greyhound is released

definitions: a situation in which people lie in wait to make a surprise attack

examples.text: we were fed false information by a double agent and walked straight into a trap

shortDefinitions: situation in which people lie in wait to make attack

definitions: a trick by which someone is misled into acting contrary to their interests or intentions

examples.text: by keeping quiet I was walking into a trap

shortDefinitions: trick by which someone is misled into acting

definitions: an unpleasant situation from which it is hard to escape

examples.text: they fell into the trap of relying too little on equity financing

shortDefinitions: unpleasant situation that is hard to escape

definitions: a container or device used to collect a specified thing

examples.text: one fuel filter and water trap are sufficient on the fuel system

shortDefinitions: container or device used to collect something

definitions: a curve in the waste pipe from a bathtub, sink, or toilet that is always full of liquid and prevents gases from coming up the pipe into the building.
shortDefinitions: curve in waste pipe

definitions: a bunker or other hollow on a golf course.
shortDefinitions: bunker on golf course

definitions: a light, two-wheeled carriage pulled by a horse or pony.
shortDefinitions: carriage pulled by horse or pony

definitions: a device for hurling an object such as a clay pigeon into the air to be shot at.
shortDefinitions: device for hurling object into air

definitions: (in the game of trapball) the shoe-shaped device that is hit with a bat to send the ball into the air.
shortDefinitions: device hit with bat to send ball into air

definitions: a person's mouth (used in expressions to do with speaking)
shortDefinitions: person's mouth

definitions: (among jazz musicians) drums or percussion instruments

examples.text: I played the traps a little myself once

shortDefinitions: (among jazz musicians) drums

definitions: a type of hip-hop music typically characterized by a dark tone and rhythms involving low-pitched kick drums and a very fast hi-hat
etymologies: early 21st century: from trap (sense 10 of the noun), with reference to early albums like rapper T.I.'s Trap Muzik (2003) that originated the sound

examples.text: the LP will feature his raps over a wide range of electronic sounds from dubstep to trap

shortDefinitions: type of hip-hop music with dark, gritty tone

definitions: a place where drugs are sold
shortDefinitions: place where drugs are sold

definitions: an act of trapping the ball.
shortDefinitions: act of trapping ball

definitions: catch (an animal) in a trap.
shortDefinitions: catch animal in trap

definitions: prevent (someone) from escaping from a place

examples.text: twenty workers were trapped by flames

shortDefinitions: prevent someone from escaping from place

definitions: have (something, typically a part of the body) held tightly by something so that it cannot move or be freed

examples.text: he had trapped his finger in a spring-loaded hinge

shortDefinitions: have something held tightly by something so that it cannot move or be freed

definitions: induce (someone), by means of trickery or deception, to do something they would not otherwise want to do

examples.text: I hoped to trap him into an admission

shortDefinitions: induce someone, by means of trickery or deception, to do something they would not otherwise want to do

definitions: catch (the ball) after it has briefly touched the ground.
shortDefinitions: catch ball after it has briefly touched ground

definitions: bring (the ball) under control with the feet or other part of the body on receiving it.
shortDefinitions: bring ball under control with feet or other part of body on receiving it

etymologies: late Middle English: from the obsolete noun trap ‘trappings’, from Old French drap‘drape’

definitions: put trappings on (a horse)

examples.text: the horses were trapped with black velvet

shortDefinitions: put trappings on

etymologies: late 18th century: from Swedish trapp, from trappa ‘stair’ (because of the often stair-like appearance of its outcroppings)

definitions: basalt or a similar dark, fine-grained igneous rock.
shortDefinitions: basalt or similar dark, fine-grained igneous rock
